citations.narrative:
During review of facility disposition records, it was noted that the young kangaroo that had escaped during movement to
winter housing on 10/31/2024 died the day it was captured on 11/13/2024. Facility records noted that the kangaroo got
away from caretakers on 10/31/24 while the group was being moved from their outdoor enclosure to inside a heated
building for winter. The facility knew where the kangaroo was within the perimeter fence but was unable to catch it until
11/13/24. The attending veterinarian (AV) reported to us that the facility consulted him during the time it was out of its
enclosure regarding its welfare, but was not involved in the capturing process. Facility representatives said on the
morning of 11/13/24, they were able to catch the animal by cornering and throwing a tarp over it; and then brought it
inside and noticed that it was acting stressed and weak. According to the AV, the facility contacted him immediately and
were instructed to provide supportive care. The facility noted that they followed the AV's instructions, checked on the
kangaroo often throughout the day and did not note problems, but it died around midnight.
Conditions that require wild and exotic animals to be captured are known to cause stress in the animals. Allowing the
kangaroo to be out of its normal environment and group for 2 weeks while temperature lows approached freezing can
cause unnecessary stress, discomfort, and illness. Ensure that movement methods (between different enclosures) and
capture methods are done with care to avoid conditions that cause behavioral stress and physical harm to the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
During review of facility disposition records, it was noted that the young kangaroo that had escaped during movement to 
winter housing on 10/31/2024 died the day it was captured on 11/13/2024. Facility records noted that the kangaroo got 
away from caretakers on 10/31/24 while the group was being moved from their outdoor enclosure to inside a heated 
building for winter. The facility knew where the kangaroo was within the perimeter fence but was unable to catch it until 
11/13/24. The attending veterinarian (AV) reported to us that the facility consulted him during the time it was out of its 
enclosure regarding its welfare, but was not involved in the capturing process. Facility representatives said on the 
morning of 11/13/24, they were able to catch the animal by cornering and throwing a tarp over it; and then brought it 
inside and noticed that it was acting stressed and weak. According to the AV, the facility contacted him immediately and 
were instructed to provide supportive care. The facility noted that they followed the AV's instructions, checked on the 
kangaroo often throughout the day and did not note problems, but it died around midnight.  
 
Conditions that require wild and exotic animals to be captured are known to cause stress in the animals. Allowing the 
kangaroo to be out of its normal environment and group for 2 weeks while temperature lows approached freezing can 
cause unnecessary stress, discomfort, and illness. Ensure that movement methods (between different enclosures) and 
capture methods are done with care to avoid conditions that cause behavioral stress and physical harm to the animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
